content:
Yes, one example of how the DHS has used privacy-enhancing technologies to detect threat actors is through the use of Automated Targeting System (ATS) and Advanced Targeting System (ATS-P) programs. 

ATS is an intelligence-driven automated system that identifies potential high-risk travelers by analyzing data from multiple sources, including travel reservations, passenger manifests, and customs information. The system assigns scores to individuals based on risk assessments, which are used by DHS officials to determine whether additional scrutiny is needed when the individuals enter the country.

ATS-P is a more advanced version of ATS that uses machine learning, predictive analytics, and other technologies to analyze and identify more complex, high-risk travelers. The system applies a layered approach to risk assessment, using multiple data points to identify potential threats to national security.

Both ATS and ATS-P incorporate privacy-enhancing technologies, including anonymity of the data, role-based access controls, and data minimization techniques such as discarding data that does not contribute to the risk assessment. The DHS has also established an oversight board and implemented privacy policies to ensure that the use of these systems is consistent with privacy and civil liberties protections.

In summary, the DHS has used privacy-enhancing technologies to detect threat actors by creating automated systems that can identify potential high-risk travelers while minimizing the collection and use of personal data.
